dt: {bc}to confront with assured power of resistance {bc}{sx|disregard||}

dt.t: in trouble for {wi}defying{/wi} a court order

dt: {bc}to challenge to do something considered impossible {bc}{sx|dare||}

dt.t: {it}defied{/it} us to name a better movie

et: Middle English {it}defien{/it} "to renounce, disavow, scorn, challenge to fight," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}defier, desfier,{/it} from {it}de-, des-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} + {it}fier{/it} "to pledge, trust in, rely on," going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*fīdāre,{/it} re-formation of Latin {it}fīdere{/it} "to trust (in), have confidence (in)" {ma}{mat|faith:1|}{/ma}
The sense history was perhaps "to break faith with" > "to scorn" > "to challenge to a fight," though the latter meaning appears to be the earliest in Old French.
shortdef: to confront with assured power of resistance : disregard
to challenge to do something considered impossible : dare
